title: Recycling Basics and Benefits | US EPA - U.S. EPA.gov
summary: The article discusses recycling as a process that collects and processes materials to create new products, highlighting its benefits for the environment, economy, and communities. It outlines the environmental advantages, such as conserving natural resources, reducing climate change impacts, and providing economic benefits through job creation. The article also addresses challenges faced by the recycling system and mentions various initiatives to improve the U.S. recycling and waste management infrastructure.

business_innovation: FALSE - The article does not discuss a new or improved product or business process that has been introduced to the market.
green_product: FALSE - The article does not specify a particular good or service that qualifies as a green product.
green_process: TRUE - Recycling is identified as a process that minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability by efficiently managing waste.

title: Plastic bottles and bags to be made with more recycled content - Islands' Weekly
summary: The Washington Department of Ecology has introduced new regulations to increase the recycled content in plastic packaging, requiring companies to use more recycled plastic in their products. As of January, trash bags and beverage containers must contain at least 10% and 15% recycled content, respectively, with these requirements gradually increasing over the next 12 years. This initiative aims to address plastic pollution and promote sustainability by cutting down on harmful greenhouse gas emissions. The new regulations follow a law aimed at reducing single-use plastics in the state.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is considered green innovation because it promotes environmental sustainability by increasing the recycled plastic content in packaging, which helps reduce plastic pollution and greenhouse gas emissions.
business_innovation: TRUE: This represents business innovation as it involves new regulatory requirements for companies, changing their production processes significantly to include a specified percentage of recycled materials in their packaging.
green_product: TRUE: The products mentioned, such as trash bags and beverage containers with increased recycled content, align with the definition of green products as they are designed and manufactured to reduce environmental impact through the use of recycled materials.
green_process: TRUE: The processes involved in incorporating a higher percentage of recycled plastics into manufacturing and production represent green processes as they aim to minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 326199 - All Other Plastics Product Manufacturing, 312112 - Bottled Water Manufacturing, 325611 - Soap and Other Detergent Manufacturing, 444190 - Other Building Material Dealers
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not suggest greenwashing, as it outlines specific regulations aimed at enhancing recycling and reducing plastic waste, with direct support from the Washington Department of Ecology.

title: Amcor and NOVA Chemicals announce agreement to source mechanically recycled polyethylene USA - English ... - PR Newswire
summary: Amcor has announced a collaboration with NOVA Chemicals to purchase mechanically recycled polyethylene resin (rPE) for flexible packaging films as part of their commitment to packaging circularity. NOVA Chemicals is set to open a recycling facility in Indiana to support this initiative. The partnership aims to increase the usage of recycled materials in packaging, helping both companies achieve sustainability goals and reduce plastic waste. This collaboration reflects a shared commitment to promoting a circular economy in the packaging industry.
green_innovation: TRUE - This innovation supports environmental sustainability by increasing the use of recycled materials, thereby promoting circularity in packaging and reducing plastic waste.
business_innovation: TRUE - The collaboration between Amcor and NOVA Chemicals represents a new business process aimed at integrating recycled polyethylene into their product offerings, significantly differing from their previous practices.
green_product: TRUE - The mechanically recycled polyethylene resin (rPE) qualifies as a green product as it is designed to minimize environmental impact through its lifecycle by being made from recycled materials.
green_process: TRUE - The establishment of NOVA Chemicals' mechanical recycling facility represents a green process because it focuses on recycling to reduce waste and the environmental impact of plastic production.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 326160 - Plastics Bag and Film Manufacturing, 325211 - Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing, 321999 - All Other Miscellaneous Wood Product Manufacturing, 424590 - Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not indicate any false or misleading statements about environmental benefits; rather, it discusses a genuine collaboration aimed at sustainability.

title: Australia strengthens packaging standards with new national laws - Packaging Gateway
summary: Australia's national environmental ministers have agreed to develop new packaging standards aimed at facilitating a transition to a circular economy, setting minimum recycled content requirements and prohibiting harmful chemicals in packaging. The legislation holds businesses accountable for 6.7 million tonnes of packaging waste, while calling for a national traceability framework to boost consumer confidence in recycled materials. The Australian Food and Grocery Council emphasizes the importance of adequate recycling systems to support these initiatives, with some states already enacting bans on single-use plastics.
green_innovation: TRUE: The article discusses new packaging standards that contribute to environmental sustainability by promoting a circular economy, reducing waste, and setting recycled content requirements.
business_innovation: TRUE: The packaging standards represent a significant improvement in business processes for companies that produce and dispose of packaging materials, involving new regulations that have been introduced in the market.
green_product: FALSE: The article does not mention any specific product that meets the definition of a green product; it discusses standards and regulations rather than a specific good.
green_process: TRUE: The development of new packaging standards and a traceability framework represents a green process aimed at minimizing environmental impacts through improved recycling and sustainable practices.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 322211 - Corrugated and Solid Fiber Box Manufacturing, 326199 - All Other Plastics Product Manufacturing, 339999 - All Other Miscellaneous Manufacturing, 488320 - Marine Cargo Handling
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not appear to be an example of greenwashing, as it describes concrete legislative actions aimed at improving environmental sustainability rather than making misleading claims.

title: Parliament votes to water down EU's packaging waste law - EURACTIV
summary: The European Parliament has adopted a position on new legislation aimed at reducing packaging waste in the EU, but key measures focused on reuse and bans were weakened amid political division and lobbying. While the law sets targets for reducing plastic packaging and aims to encourage recycling, environmental organizations criticized the dilution of reuse provisions and the removal of bans on unnecessary packaging. Industry groups expressed satisfaction with some legislative changes, but concerns remain about the impact of these amendments on waste reduction goals.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the legislation addresses the reduction of packaging waste and promotes recycling and reuse, which are aligned with environmental sustainability and waste reduction goals.
business_innovation: FALSE, as the article discusses legislative measures rather than a new or improved product or business process introduced by a firm.
green_product: FALSE, because the article does not specify a particular good or service designed to significantly reduce environmental impact.
green_process: FALSE, as the article does not describe any specific operational activity or method that minimizes environmental impacts.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325, 424, 541, 562 (325 - Chemical Manufacturing, 424 - Merchant Wholesalers, Nondurable Goods, 541 - Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services, 562 - Waste Management and Remediation Services)
greenwashing: FALSE, as the article does not suggest that the measures discussed are misleading or exaggerated in their environmental benefits; it highlights a genuine attempt at legislative reform with criticism mainly focused on the weakening of certain provisions.

title: New York calls PepsiCo's plastic pollution a 'public nuisance' in first-of-its-kind lawsuit - Grist
summary: PepsiCo is facing a lawsuit from New York Attorney General Letitia James over its role in plastic pollution in the Buffalo River watershed. The lawsuit claims that PepsiCo's plastic packaging is a significant contributor to environmental harm and public health risks, prompting the state to seek reductions in plastic use and public warnings about the risks of single-use plastics. Despite claims of sustainability and circular economy practices, the company has reportedly increased its virgin plastic use and failed to meet its plastic reduction targets. The case highlights the growing legal scrutiny over plastic pollution and corporate responsibility.
green_innovation: TRUE: The article discusses environmental harm caused by PepsiCo's plastic packaging, leading to a lawsuit aimed at reducing plastic waste and its toxic effects.
business_innovation: FALSE: The article does not present new or improved products or processes introduced by PepsiCo, but rather critiques their existing practices.
green_product: FALSE: The article discusses the environmental issues related to PepsiCo's plastic packaging but does not define it as a green product.
green_process: FALSE: The article talks about PepsiCo's practices but does not describe any new methods or techniques that minimize environmental impact.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311920 - Snack Food Manufacturing, 312111 - Soft Drink Manufacturing, 424490 - Other Grocery and Related Product Merchant Wholesalers, 339999 - All Other Miscellaneous Manufacturing
greenwashing: TRUE: The article depicts potential greenwashing as PepsiCo promoted its recycling strategy while actually increasing plastic production and not achieving sustainability targets.

title: Expanded Polystyrene (EPS) Industry Advances Sustainability with $185M Investment in Recycled Content Resin ... - PR Web
summary: The article discusses the introduction of recycled content resin in the expanded polystyrene (EPS) industry, highlighting its potential to significantly reduce environmental impacts, including lower energy consumption and carbon footprint. With growing regulatory pressures and a shift in market demand for sustainable materials, EPS resin producers are adapting to these changes and promoting the environmental benefits of their innovations. The EPS Industry Alliance is advocating for responsible EPS use and positively influencing sustainability through research-backed policies.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the innovation involves the use of recycled content resin, which reduces environmental impacts and supports sustainability goals such as reduced resource consumption and waste.
business_innovation: TRUE, as it describes a new product offering (recycled content resin) that significantly differs from previous business processes and products in the EPS industry.
green_product: TRUE, as recycled content resin is designed and used to significantly reduce environmental impacts throughout its life cycle, aligning with the definition of a green product.
green_process: TRUE, as the processes involved in producing recycled content resin aim to minimize environmental impacts, including waste reduction and lower energy consumption.

title: Five million bales wrapped with Trioworld's bale wrap with post-consumer recycled content - Mynewsdesk
summary: Trioworld launched the first-ever Post-Consumer Recyclates (PCR) based bale wrap at Agritechnica 2019 and now offers a full range of premium products for baled silage with recycled content. The bale wrap is produced from recycled materials, which promotes circularity and reduces the carbon footprint significantly. Trioworld aims to have 30% PCR in all products by 2025, highlighting the sustainability of its manufacturing practices.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation because it contributes to environmental sustainability by using post-consumer recycled materials, promoting circularity, and reducing carbon footprint.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation because it introduces a new product (bale wrap made from recycled materials) that significantly differs from Trioworld's previous products.
green_product: TRUE: This is a green product because it is designed to minimize environmental impact through the use of recycled materials and supports sustainability throughout its life cycle.
green_process: TRUE: This is a green process because Trioworld recycles used bale wrap into new high-performance films, reducing waste and promoting resource efficiency.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325211 - Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing, 326199 - All Other Plastics Product Manufacturing, 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 322211 - Paper (except Newsprint) Mills
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not describe greenwashing, as Trioworld provides verifiable details about their sustainable practices and the effectiveness of their recycled products.

title: PharmaCos, Stoelzle Pharma's new packaging line for wellbeing products - Premium beauty
summary: The article discusses the launch of the PharmaCos line by Stoelzle Pharma, featuring a range of glass packaging solutions designed for healthcare products. The new line incorporates high recycled glass content and lightweight designs, manufactured in a pharmaceutical-grade environment. Stoelzle offers various caps and closures, including eco-friendly decoration techniques using recycled materials.

summary: The article discusses a variety of innovative seating, lighting, and acoustic solutions featured on Dezeen Showroom, which focus on environmental sustainability and functionality. It highlights products like the Plega seating collection, which utilizes recycled materials, and other designs that balance aesthetics with sound control and ergonomic features.
